reasoning: The critique targets a fairly central plank of the essay’s optimism: that even without widespread convergence, partial AM-convergence plus moral trade/compromise can still yield mostly-great futures. If trade were infeasible under the described divergence, the essay’s main positive pathway would be substantially weakened (though not the whole essay, since it also discusses other mechanisms and remains uncertain overall). However, the critique overstates the inconsistency: the essay’s “divergence” is mainly about failure to converge on the same ultimate values, not necessarily mutual unintelligibility. Trade can work with divergent values via preference revelation, bargaining over resources, and superintelligent delegates/contracting (which the essay explicitly invokes) without requiring shared ethical understanding. Still, the critique usefully presses an under-argued assumption: that future agents can stably model each other’s preferences, find Pareto improvements, and verify/commit to agreements even across very alien value systems. That’s a real gap but not a decisive refutation.
title: Radical divergence undermines the mutual comprehension needed for moral trade
